articles.headline: Treating Pain Without Feeding Addiction at Epicenter for Opioids
articles.snippet: The difficult work of addressing the nation’s overreliance on opioids, while also treating debilitating pain, is playing out patient by patient in West Virginia.
articles.abstract: The difficult work of addressing the nation’s overreliance on opioids, while also treating debilitating pain, is playing out patient by patient in West Virginia.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, W.Va. — The doctors wanted to talk about illness, but the patients — often miners, waitresses, tree cutters and others whose jobs were punishingly physical — wanted to talk only about how much they hurt. They kept pleading for opioids like Vicodin and Percocet, the potent drugs that can help chronic pain, but that have fueled an epidemic of addiction and deadly overdoses.

articles.headline: Canada Fire Deals Staggering Blow to Oil Sands Industry and Economy
articles.snippet: Companies either curbed production or shut down completely when the blaze struck Fort McMurray, Alberta, in an economic setback to the region.
articles.abstract: Companies either curbed production or shut down completely when the blaze struck Fort McMurray, Alberta, in an economic setback to the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta — Oversize transport trailers typically barrel dangerously along Highway 63 as they deliver heavy loads of equipment and even prefabricated metal buildings to the multibillion-dollar oil sands projects that dominate this area. But more than a dozen such trailers, still full, now sit at pull-ins and rest stops, abandoned by drivers who unhitched their tractors and fled south on warnings of a devastating forest fire.

articles.headline: Congo Lurches Toward a New Crisis as Leader Tries to Crush a Rival
articles.snippet: Moïse Katumbi, a popular opposition politician, is the greatest threat to President Joseph Kabila’s rule. He and his supporters are now being targeted by Mr. Kabila’s security services.
articles.abstract: Moïse Katumbi, a popular opposition politician, is the greatest threat to President Joseph Kabila’s rule. He and his supporters are now being targeted by Mr. Kabila’s security services.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUBUMBASHI, Democratic Republic of Congo — As hundreds of police officers ringed the courthouse, the mob came barreling up the street. From blocks away, you could hear its hungry roar.

articles.headline: Lack of Plan for ISIS Detainees Raises Human Rights Concerns
articles.snippet: The United States, determined not to get back into detention operations, has no strategy in place for handling potentially thousands of war prisoners.
articles.abstract: The United States, determined not to get back into detention operations, has no strategy in place for handling potentially thousands of war prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State calls them “inghimasi” — zealous foot soldiers who intend to fight to their deaths. And as the American-backed coalition has reclaimed territory from the group in Iraq and Syria, that fervor has kept prisoners from being much of a problem: The shooting only stops when almost every Islamic State fighter has been killed.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Valeant Promised Price Breaks on Drugs. Heart Hospitals Are Still Waiting.
articles.snippet: Several hospitals say nothing has changed since Valeant vowed to look into assertions that no hospital could be found that had received a discount.
articles.abstract: Several hospitals say nothing has changed since Valeant vowed to look into assertions that no hospital could be found that had received a discount.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Clinic is widely seen as the top heart hospital in the country, so when Valeant Pharmaceuticals International pledged to Congress that it would offer hospitals breaks of as much as 30 percent on two of its expensive heart drugs, officials at the hospital figured they would hear from the company soon.

articles.headline: Pentagon Turns to Silicon Valley for Edge in Artificial Intelligence
articles.snippet: Secretary of Defense Ashton B. Carter takes his bridge-building message to Silicon Valley despite skepticism among some in the tech community.
articles.abstract: Secretary of Defense Ashton B. Carter takes his bridge-building message to Silicon Valley despite skepticism among some in the tech community.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — In its quest to maintain a United States military advantage, the Pentagon is aggressively turning to Silicon Valley’s hottest technology — artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Look for Hard Hats in a Year of Collapsing Mergers
articles.snippet: Since the beginning of January, $400 billion worth of corporate mergers have fallen apart in the United States, creating anxiety in those who bet on them.
articles.abstract: Since the beginning of January, $400 billion worth of corporate mergers have fallen apart in the United States, creating anxiety in those who bet on them.
articles.lead_paragraph: While last year set a record for the amount of money spent on corporate mergers — $4.7 trillion — this year is so far setting a very different record: the dollar amount of deals that have come undone.

articles.headline: Ryan Caught Between Desire for Republican Unity and Future Agenda
articles.snippet: Speaker Paul D. Ryan may be forced to acquiesce to Donald Trump in the name of Republican unity or establish himself as the party’s leading voice of opposition.
articles.abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan may be forced to acquiesce to Donald Trump in the name of Republican unity or establish himself as the party’s leading voice of opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As his party splinters and his policy agenda faces peril, Speaker Paul D. Ryan will enter his meeting with Donald J. Trump on Thursday increasingly at odds with a growing, if grudging, Republican congressional majority willing to embrace Mr. Trump as their candidate.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Donald Trump and Paul Ryan Show Signs of Thaw
articles.snippet: Speaker Paul D. Ryan came away from his meeting with Donald J. Trump feeling positive, though Mr. Ryan still did not endorse him.
articles.abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan came away from his meeting with Donald J. Trump feeling positive, though Mr. Ryan still did not endorse him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump and Speaker Paul D. Ryan appeared to take half a step back from their political standoff on Thursday, as Mr. Trump toured Washington for a swirl of meetings with Republican lawmakers concerned about the direction of his presidential campaign.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Alexander Burns
